description: From Middle English couple, from Old French couple, from Latin cōpula. Doublet of copula.

entries.meaning: (informal, US) Two or (a) small number of.
Two of the same kind connected or considered together.
examples: A couple of police officers appeared at the door.

entries.meaning: Two partners in a romantic or sexual relationship.
examples: I calculate there may be about two hundred thousand couple whose wives are breeders;  […]
‘Oh, merely a couple of hundred a year, but the work is slight, and it need not interfere very much with one’s other occupations.’

entries.meaning: One of the pairs of plates of two metals which compose a voltaic battery, called a voltaic couple or galvanic couple.
(physics) A turning effect created by forces that sum to zero in magnitude but produce a non-zero external torque.
That which joins or links two things together; a bond or tie; a coupler.

verbs.description: couple (third-person singular simple present couples, present participle coupling, simple past and past participle coupled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To join (two things) together, or (one thing) to (another).
examples: Now the conductor will couple the train cars.
I've coupled our system to theirs.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To join in wedlock; to marry.
(intransitive) To join in sexual intercourse; to copulate.
examples: On their wedding night they coupled nine times.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (two animals) to copulate, to bring (two animals) together for mating.
